deck.name: The Soldier's Guide
deck.description: TC 7-21.13 - Comprehensive coverage of Army Values, ranks, customs, drill, and military justice

metadata.title: The Soldier's Guide
metadata.proponent: United States Army Combined Arms Center

cards.front: What are the seven Army Values?
cards.back:
Loyalty, Duty, Respect, Selfless Service, Honor, Integrity, and Personal Courage (LDRSHIP).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-1)

cards.front: Define the Army Value: LOYALTY
cards.back:
Bear true faith and allegiance to the U.S. Constitution, the Army, your unit, and other Soldiers.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-2)

cards.front: Define the Army Value: DUTY
cards.back:
Fulfill your obligations. Accept responsibility for your own actions and those entrusted to your care.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-3)

cards.front: Define the Army Value: RESPECT
cards.back:
Treat people as they should be treated.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-4)

cards.front: Define the Army Value: SELFLESS SERVICE
cards.back:
Put the welfare of the Nation, the Army, and your subordinates before your own.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-5)

cards.front: Define the Army Value: HONOR
cards.back:
Live up to all the Army Values.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-6)

cards.front: Define the Army Value: INTEGRITY
cards.back:
Do what is right, legally and morally.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-7)

cards.front: Define the Army Value: PERSONAL COURAGE
cards.back:
Face fear, danger, or adversity (physical or moral).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What are the four tenets of the Warrior Ethos?
cards.back:
1. I will always place the mission first
2. I will never accept defeat
3. I will never quit
4. I will never leave a fallen comrade

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-10)

cards.front: What is the Army motto?
cards.back:
"This We'll Defend."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-15)

cards.front: When was the United States Army established?
cards.back:
14 June 1775.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-14)

cards.front: What is the NCO watchword?
cards.back:
Competence.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-12)

cards.front: What are the two basic responsibilities of an NCO?
cards.back:
1. Accomplishment of the mission
2. Welfare of Soldiers

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-12)

cards.front: What is the NCO Corps known as?
cards.back:
"The Backbone of the Army."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-12)

cards.front: What rank is E-1?
cards.back:
Private (PV1). No insignia.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is E-2?
cards.back:
Private (PV2). One chevron.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is E-3?
cards.back:
Private First Class (PFC). One chevron, one rocker.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is E-4?
cards.back:
Specialist (SPC) or Corporal (CPL). SPC has eagle; CPL has two chevrons.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is E-5?
cards.back:
Sergeant (SGT). Three chevrons.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is E-6?
cards.back:
Staff Sergeant (SSG). Three chevrons, one rocker.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is E-7?
cards.back:
Sergeant First Class (SFC). Three chevrons, two rockers.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is E-8?
cards.back:
Master Sergeant (MSG) or First Sergeant (1SG). Three chevrons, three rockers. 1SG has diamond.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is E-9?
cards.back:
Sergeant Major (SGM), Command Sergeant Major (CSM), or Sergeant Major of the Army (SMA).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What distinguishes a First Sergeant (1SG) from a Master Sergeant (MSG)?
cards.back:
The 1SG has a diamond in the center of the insignia. 1SG is a leadership position; MSG is a technical position.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-20)

cards.front: What rank is O-1?
cards.back:
Second Lieutenant (2LT). One gold bar.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-2?
cards.back:
First Lieutenant (1LT). One silver bar.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-3?
cards.back:
Captain (CPT). Two silver bars (railroad tracks).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-4?
cards.back:
Major (MAJ). Gold oak leaf.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-5?
cards.back:
Lieutenant Colonel (LTC). Silver oak leaf.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-6?
cards.back:
Colonel (COL). Silver eagle.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-7?
cards.back:
Brigadier General (BG). One star.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-8?
cards.back:
Major General (MG). Two stars.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-9?
cards.back:
Lieutenant General (LTG). Three stars.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is O-10?
cards.back:
General (GEN). Four stars.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-21)

cards.front: What rank is WO1?
cards.back:
Warrant Officer One. Silver bar with black square.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-22)

cards.front: What rank is CW2?
cards.back:
Chief Warrant Officer Two. Silver bar with two black squares.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-22)

cards.front: What rank is CW3?
cards.back:
Chief Warrant Officer Three. Silver bar with three black squares.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-22)

cards.front: What rank is CW4?
cards.back:
Chief Warrant Officer Four. Silver bar with four black squares.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-22)

cards.front: What rank is CW5?
cards.back:
Chief Warrant Officer Five. Silver bar with black stripe.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 2, para 2-22)

cards.front: Who salutes first?
cards.back:
The junior member always salutes first.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-1)

cards.front: When do you salute outdoors?
cards.back:
When you meet or pass a commissioned or warrant officer.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-2)

cards.front: When do you salute during music/ceremonies?
cards.back:
During the National Anthem, "To the Color," "Hail to the Chief," or when uncased colors pass.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: Do you salute indoors?
cards.back:
No, except when reporting to a superior officer or when under arms.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: Do you salute while in a military vehicle?
cards.back:
No, occupants of vehicles do not salute.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: Do you salute while carrying items with both hands?
cards.back:
No, when impractical, render a verbal greeting instead.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you address an officer?
cards.back:
Use "Sir" or "Ma'am."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-13)

cards.front: How do you address an NCO (E-5 to E-8)?
cards.back:
Address them as "Sergeant" or by full rank ("Staff Sergeant").

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-14)

cards.front: How do you address a Sergeant Major (E-9)?
cards.back:
"Sergeant Major."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-14)

cards.front: What should you do outdoors when "Reveille" is played?
cards.back:
Face the flag, stand at attention, and salute during "To the Color."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-21)

cards.front: What should you do outdoors when "Retreat" is played?
cards.back:
Stop, face the flag, and stand at attention. Salute when "To the Color" plays.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-22)

cards.front: What is the proper response when the National Anthem plays outdoors?
cards.back:
Face the flag (or music), stand at attention, and salute from first to last note.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-23)

cards.front: What is the correct position of the U.S. flag when displayed with other flags?
cards.back:
To its own right (observer's left) and raised first, lowered last.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-27)

cards.front: Should the U.S. flag ever be dipped?
cards.back:
No, the U.S. flag is never dipped to any person or thing.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-30)

cards.front: What is a 'rank' in drill?
cards.back:
A line of Soldiers placed side by side.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: What is a 'file' in drill?
cards.back:
A column of Soldiers placed one behind the other.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: What is 'normal interval' in formation?
cards.back:
One arm's length (approximately 30 inches).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-4)

cards.front: What is 'close interval' in formation?
cards.back:
Approximately 4 inches (shoulder to shoulder).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-4)

cards.front: What are the two parts of a drill command?
cards.back:
Preparatory command and command of execution.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What is the length of a normal marching step?
cards.back:
30 inches.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-9)

cards.front: How many steps per minute is quick time?
cards.back:
120 steps per minute.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-9)

cards.front: How many steps per minute is double time?
cards.back:
180 steps per minute.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-9)

cards.front: What is the position of Attention?
cards.back:
Heels together, feet at 45°, arms at sides, thumbs along trouser seams, head erect.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-11)

cards.front: On "Parade, REST" where do your hands go?
cards.back:
Small of the back, right hand over left, fingers extended and joined.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-12)

cards.front: How far does the left foot move on "Parade, REST"?
cards.back:
10 inches to the left.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-12)

cards.front: What is the difference between "At Ease" and "Rest"?
cards.back:
At Ease: Keep right foot in place, remain silent. Rest: May move and talk, but keep right foot in place.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-13)

cards.front: What command allows movement and talking?
cards.back:
"REST" or "Fall Out."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-13)

cards.front: On what foot does "HALT" execute?
cards.back:
Right foot (take one more step with left, then bring right alongside).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-18)

cards.front: What is the command to execute a right turn while marching?
cards.back:
"Right turn, MARCH" or "Column right, MARCH."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-22)

cards.front: How do you execute "About, FACE" from attention?
cards.back:
Pivot 180° to the right on the heel of the right foot and ball of the left foot.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-17)

cards.front: What is the command to change from quick time to double time?
cards.back:
"Double time, MARCH."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-20)

cards.front: What is the command to change from double time to quick time?
cards.back:
"Quick time, MARCH."

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 4, para 4-20)

cards.front: What does UCMJ stand for?
cards.back:
Uniform Code of Military Justice.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-1)

cards.front: What is Article 15?
cards.back:
Non-judicial punishment. Allows commanders to punish minor offenses without a court-martial.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-3)

cards.front: Can a Soldier refuse Article 15?
cards.back:
Yes, a Soldier has the right to demand trial by court-martial instead.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-3)

cards.front: What is a Summary Court-Martial?
cards.back:
For minor offenses. Maximum punishment: 30 days confinement.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What is a Special Court-Martial?
cards.back:
For intermediate offenses. Maximum: 12 months confinement.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What is a General Court-Martial?
cards.back:
For most serious offenses. Can impose any authorized punishment, including death.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What is Article 86 of the UCMJ?
cards.back:
Absence Without Leave (AWOL).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What is Article 91 of the UCMJ?
cards.back:
Insubordinate conduct toward a warrant officer, NCO, or petty officer.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What is Article 92 of the UCMJ?
cards.back:
Failure to obey an order or regulation.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What is Article 134 of the UCMJ?
cards.back:
The "General Article" - covers conduct prejudicial to good order and discipline.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What is General Order 1 for guard duty?
cards.back:
I will guard everything within the limits of my post and quit my post only when properly relieved.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-12)

cards.front: What is General Order 2 for guard duty?
cards.back:
I will obey my special orders and perform all my duties in a military manner.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-12)

cards.front: What is General Order 3 for guard duty?
cards.back:
I will report violations of my special orders, emergencies, and anything not covered in my instructions.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-12)

cards.front: What is the Code of Conduct?
cards.back:
Six articles prescribing how Soldiers conduct themselves in combat and captivity.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-15)

cards.front: What is Article I of the Code of Conduct?
cards.back:
I am an American, fighting in the forces which guard my country. I am prepared to give my life in their defense.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-16)

cards.front: What is Article II of the Code of Conduct?
cards.back:
I will never surrender of my own free will.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-16)

cards.front: What is Article III of the Code of Conduct?
cards.back:
If captured, I will continue to resist. I will make every effort to escape.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-16)

cards.front: What is Article IV of the Code of Conduct?
cards.back:
If a POW, I will keep faith with my fellow prisoners. If senior, I will take command.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-16)

cards.front: What is Article V of the Code of Conduct?
cards.back:
If questioned as a POW, I give only name, rank, service number, and date of birth.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-16)

cards.front: What is Article VI of the Code of Conduct?
cards.back:
I will never forget that I am an American, responsible for my actions, and dedicated to freedom.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-16)

cards.front: What four pieces of information may a POW give?
cards.back:
Name, Rank, Service Number, Date of Birth.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 6, para 6-17)

cards.front: What does the term "chain of command" mean?
cards.back:
The succession of leaders through which command authority is exercised.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 1, para 1-5)

cards.front: Who is the Commander in Chief of the U.S. Armed Forces?
cards.back:
The President of the United States.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 1, para 1-5)

cards.front: What is the difference between a command and a staff position?
cards.back:
Command positions have authority over units. Staff positions advise and assist commanders.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 1, para 1-8)

cards.front: What is the purpose of military courtesy?
cards.back:
To show respect and develop teamwork among Soldiers.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-16)

cards.front: What is the proper procedure when entering an officer's office?
cards.back:
Knock, enter when told, approach within two paces, salute, and report.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-15)

cards.front: What does "rendering honors" mean?
cards.back:
Showing respect through salutes, attention, or other prescribed actions.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-24)

cards.front: When walking with a senior, where should the junior be?
cards.back:
On the senior's left (the position of honor is on the right).

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-18)

cards.front: What is a "guidon"?
cards.back:
A swallow-tailed flag that identifies a company, battery, troop, or detachment.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-36)

cards.front: What does "colors" refer to?
cards.back:
The national flag and organizational flag of a unit.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-33)

cards.front: What is "half-staff" (half-mast)?
cards.back:
The flag is flown at half the height of the pole as a sign of mourning.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-31)

cards.front: When is the flag flown at half-staff?
cards.back:
On Memorial Day (until noon), death of officials, or as ordered by the President.

(Source: TC 7-21.13, Ch 3, para 3-31)
